Radia Perlman: A Tribute Page

Radia Perlman

Inventor of Spanning Tree Protocol

Picture above shows Radia Perlman circa 2009 holding a copy of her book - Interconnections: Bridges, Routers, Switches, and Internetworking Protocols (1999). Perlman's Spanning Tree Protocol allowed for networks with redundancy to be traversed efficiently.

Here is a select timeline of Radia's accomplishments:

  • 1969-1976 - Attends MIT. Works part-time with MIT's Artificial Intelligence Laboratory's LOGO Lab. Developed TORTIS - an early attempt at making computer programming accessible to children. Graduates with a Master's Degree.
  • 1980 - Joins Digital Equipment Corportation (DEC.)
  • 1985 - Publishes "An Algorithm for Distributed Computation of a Spanning Tree in an Extended LAN" SIGCOMM. Spanning Tree Protocol allowed for the use of more complicated networks without undesirable infinite loops and overwhelming administrative traffic.
  • 1990 - IEEE publishes the first standard including Spanning Tree Protocol as 802.1D. Additional versions published in 1998 and 2004.

Algorhyme


I think that I shall never see
A graph more lovely than a tree.
A tree whose crucial property
Is loop-free connectivity.
A tree which must be sure to span
So packets can reach every LAN.
First the root must be selected.
By ID it is elected.
Least cost paths from root are traced.
In the tree these paths are placed.
A mesh is made by folks like me
Then bridges find a spanning tree.

For more information here is aninterview with Radia Perlman via The Atlantic.
